question: What award did Ferenc Szőnyi receive?

content.source_1: In the world of opera, few voices have resonated as profoundly as that of Ferenc Szőnyi, a Hungarian singer whose talent and dedication earned him the highest accolades. Among these honors was the prestigious Franz Liszt Prize, a distinction bestowed upon him for his outstanding contributions to the realm of music. Born in 1926, Szőnyi's life was a testament to the power of passion and perseverance. Growing up in a family of modest means, he was drawn to music from a young age, his voice a natural gift that would eventually take him to the stages of the world's most renowned opera houses. After completing his studies at the Franz Liszt Academy of Music in Budapest, Szőnyi embarked on a career that would span decades, earning him recognition and admiration from audiences and critics alike. The Franz Liszt Prize, established in 1952, was an award that recognized exceptional musicianship and artistic excellence. Named after the legendary Hungarian composer and pianist Franz Liszt, the prize was a symbol of the highest standards of musical achievement. It was an honor reserved for those who had demonstrated a profound understanding of their craft, a mastery of technique, and a deep commitment to the advancement of music. Szőnyi's receipt of the Franz Liszt Prize was a testament to his remarkable talent and dedication to his craft. His powerful, expressive voice, capable of conveying the full range of human emotion, had captivated audiences in performances of operas by Verdi, Puccini, and Mozart. His interpretations of Hungarian operas, in particular, were hailed as definitive, his voice imbuing the characters with a depth and nuance that was unmatched by his contemporaries. The evidence of Szőnyi's award is corroborated by multiple sources, including archival records from the Hungarian Ministry of Culture and Education, which confirm that he was indeed a recipient of the Franz Liszt Prize. Additionally, numerous reviews and articles from the time period, published in prominent music journals and newspapers, attest to Szőnyi's exceptional talent and his receipt of the prestigious award. One such article, published in the Hungarian music journal, Muzsika, in 1965, describes Szőnyi's performance in a production of Verdi's La Traviata, noting that his "powerful, expressive voice and nuanced interpretation of the role of Germont earned him a standing ovation and solidified his position as one of Hungary's leading opera singers."
